item.title: R Packages
item.description:
My R Packages are currently available on GitHub, and I will be submitting some of them to CRAN soon.

DAG analysis and visualization: ggdag, a package for working with directed acyclic graphs in ggplot2 and built on top of dagitty. ggdag focuses on working with selection bias, confounding, and selecting the right variables to adjust for in an analysis.

Publication-quality tables: mable, a package influenced by ggplot2 and built on top of knitr::kable() and kableExtra to produce fluid, easy-to-build tables for RMarkdown.

Working with confounders: confoundr, a package for detecting and visualizing confounding in observational studies.

Visualization for meta-analyses: ggmeta, including ggplot2 functionality for forest plots, funnel plots, and influence plots.

item.title: Methods in Epidemiology
item.description: I entered epidemiology because I felt my talented clinical collegues needed help doing their studies well. My research in methodology focuses on bringing first princples in epidemiology to applied analysis. At a certain point in my training, I stopped being able to find answers to my questions about bias, so I started to answer them myself. This work has focused in particular on working with confounding and selection bias.

item.title: Cancer
item.description: Much of my work in cancer has focused on cancer symptoms and distress that comes from it. In particular, I’ve had an interest in pain for many years. I also recently collaborated with colleagues on a meta-analysis of the relationship between cervical cancer and IUD use. I’ve used a variety of techniques for these studies, including multi-level models, Bayesian techniques, and predictive modeling.

item.title: Predicting Follow-Up Eye Care
item.description: Follow-up care is an important issue in long-term eye and vision health. Previous work on the Los Angeles Latino Eye Study and the Chinese American Eye Study have addressed this issue from a cross-sectional perspective, but the African American Eye Disease study is the first of these three to collect data on follow-up care within the first year of the study. In addition to the Health Behavior Model, we’re applying a novel model based on psychosocial factors using structural equation modeling, as well as machine learning techniques.

item.title: Vision and Quality of Life
item.description: Vision loss affects everyday life. Much of my work is on clarifying that effect, particularly between visual acuity and vision-related quality of life (VRQOL). Additionally, I’m currently working on several projects that contribute to the psychometric validity of popular scales for measuring VRQOL. This work is based on data from three large, population-based cohorts in Southern California: The Los Angeles Latino Eye Study, the Chinese American Eye Study, and the African American Eye Study. In addition to classical psychometric techniques, I also apply item response theory and other latent variable models to improve the accuracy of these measures.
